title: Man arrested after lying about being a white supremacist for work
text:
A New Jersey man has been arrested after he was allegedly caught lying about being a white supremacist to keep his job at a Navy Yard.

Fred Arena, 41, of Salem, New Jersey, was charged on Friday with making false statements to government agents when he tried to obtain security clearance for his job.

Arena works at the Philadelphia Navy Yard and is required to get security clearance.

He has been accused of lying to obtain the clearance by denying that he was white supremacist, according to authorities.

Arena also allegedly lied to federal investigators who asked him about his answers to questions on the security clearance paperwork.

Fred Arena, 41, of Salem, New Jersey, was charged on Friday with making false statements to government agents when he tried to obtain security clearance for his job at the Philadelphia Navy Yard

According to his indictment, Arena - who also goes by the names Big 88 and Fritz Arena - completed the standard form to obtain the security clearance on January 10.

He was required to disclose whether he had ever been a member of an organization that used, or advocated the use of, force or violence to prevent others from exercising their constitutional rights.

Authorities say he falsely answered that he had not.

Arena was an avowed member of Vanguard America, a white supremacist group that fits that description, according to the indictment.

On the same application, Arena was asked whether he had property repossessed within the past seven years.

He allegedly falsely answered that he had not despite previously defaulting on a car loan and having his vehicle repossessed.

If convicted, he faces a maximum possible sentence of 25 years in prison and a $1.2million fine.

U.S. attorney William M. McSwain described Arena's lies as 'disturbing'.

'Lying on federal security clearance forms and to government agents will land you in big trouble,' he said.

'Further, the nature of the defendant's alleged lies - attempting to conceal his affiliation with a white supremacist group in order to obtain federal employment - is extremely disturbing.'
